conclusion: Liquid is provided at positions A, B, and C on the top of the baffles.
The baffles are designed to block direct horizontal flow and allow vertical flow only.
Each baffle has a small opening that allows liquid to pass through vertically but blocks horizontal flow.
Each baffle has an opening that aligns with one of the containers (D or E) below.
The liquid will flow down vertically through these openings because the baffles are oriented to allow only this type of flow.
If the openings for D and E are aligned such that they can collect the liquid, it will flow into those respective containers.
Typically, in such setups, the liquid will flow into the container directly under the source.
Without specific details about the alignment of the openings, we can assume that the liquid will flow into the container directly under the source due to the vertical path created by the baffles.

If there is no conflicting information or additional context indicating otherwise, we assume the liquid will flow according to the most straightforward path, which is directly into the container beneath the source.
Liquid from A will flow into E.
Liquid from B will flow into D.
Liquid from C will flow into E.
If the specific alignment is not provided, the most general answer would be that the liquid will flow into the container directly below its source position relative to the baffles.
